sen.j: 常世 長胤（とこよ ながたね、天保3年（1832年） - 明治19年（1886年）3月19日）は江戸末期の国学者・明治期の神祇官。
sen.e: Nagatane TOKOYO (1832-March 19, 1886) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the end of the Edo period and Jingikan (official of the institution for dedicating to religious ceremony) in the Meiji period.

Nagatane TOKOYO (1832-March 19, 1886) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the end of the Edo period and Jingikan (official of the institution for dedicating to religious ceremony) in the Meiji period.

Nagatane TOKOYO (1832-March 19, 1886) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the end of the Edo period and Jingikan (official of the institution for dedicating to religious ceremony) in the Meiji period.
He studied under Bon HIRATA.
He studied under a study group of HIRATA.
sen.cmt: 本居門、荷田門があるように、国学の研究グループをさすものと思われます。『平田篤胤と秋田乃門人』桐原善雄著で調べました。
sen.e: He studied under a study group of HIRATA.

sen.j: 『神教組織物語』などの著作がある。
sen.e: His works include "Story of Shinto Organizations."
One of his books was "Story of Shinto Organizations" (神教組織物語).
sen.cmt: 文内に日本語表記も挿入し、訂正しました。
sen.e: One of his books was "Story of Shinto Organizations" (神教組織物語).
Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 1832年（天保3） 上総国木更津に生まれたというが、異説もある。
sen.e: It is said that he was born in Kisarazu, Kazusa Province, in 1832, but there is another belief.
It is said that he was born in Kisarazu, Kazusa Province, in 1832, but there is another belief.
It is said that he was born in Kisarazu, Kazusa Province, in 1832, but there is another belief.
He lived in Simotsuke Province.
Later, he lived in Simotsuke Province.
sen.cmt: 文頭にLaterを挿入しました。
sen.e: Later, he lived in Simotsuke Province.

sen.j: 1866年（慶応2） 平田鉄胤に入門。
sen.e: In 1866, he became a disciple of Kanetane HIRATA.
In 1866, he became a disciple of Kanetane HIRATA.
In 1866, he became a disciple of Kanetane HIRATA.

sen.j: 1872年（明治5）5月、宣教使十二等出仕から東京都港区 (東京都)芝大門鎮座の芝大神宮祠官に異動。
sen.e: In May 1872, he was transferred from a 12th-grade clerk at the Shinto Propagation Agency to the Shinto priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine, which was located in Shiba Daimon, Minato Ward, Tokyo.
In May 1872, he was transferred from a 12th-grade clerk at the Shinto Propagation Agency to the Shinto priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine, which was located in Shiba Daimon, Minato Ward, Tokyo.
In May 1872, he was transferred from a 12th-grade clerk at the Shinto Propagation Agency to the Shinto priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine, which was located in Shiba Daimon, Minato Ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 1872年（明治5）11月、芝大神宮祠官から教部省十等出仕に異動。
sen.e: In November 1872, he was transferred from a priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine to a 10th-grade official at Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion).
In November 1872, he was transferred from a priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine to a 10th-grade official at Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion).
In November 1872, he was transferred from a priest of Shiba-dai-jingu Shrine to a 10th-grade official at Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion).
In 1875, he was appointed as Gonchuzoku (middle-level official) at Shizuoka Prefecture.
In 1875, he was appointed as Gonchuzoku (middle-level official) at Shizuoka Prefecture.
In 1875, he was appointed as Gonchuzoku (middle-level official) at Shizuoka Prefecture.
In 1878, he resigned from the post.
In 1878, he resigned from the post.
In 1878, he resigned from the post.
